newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian rice prices ease on slow export demand.
newsitem.headline: Indian rice prices ease on slow export demand.

text.p: Lack of export demand for Indian non-Basmati rice pulled prices down by $5-10 per tonne during the past week, traders said on Thursday.
"No new (rice export) contracts were signed during last week," said Prem Garg, managing director of Sri Lal Mahal Overseas Ltd, a leading Delhi foodgrains exporter.
"Some shipments of old contracts (to the Middle East and Russia) were currently moving," he said.
Traders said Indian five percent broken non-Basmati rice was quoted at $290 per tonne FOB, 10 percent at $280, 15 percent at $245 and 25 percent at $230.
"There is hardly any activity in the rice market as Indian prices were ruling higher than Pakistan," said one analyst.
"But there are some inquiries for the 25 percent broken variety."
Traders reported robust demand for Basmati rice from the Middle East due to Ramadan.
"The demand for Basmati rice is good from the Middle East because of Ramadan," Garg said.
Traders said Indian parboiled Basmati was currently priced at around $780 to $800 per tonne FOB compared with $620 at the same time last year.
Raw Basmati was quoted at around $900 to $1,000 per tonne against $725 to $775 a year ago.
